Given `f : X → Y` and a topology on `Y`,
the induced topology on `X` is the collection of sets
that are preimages of some open set in `Y`.
This is the coarsest topology that makes `f` continuous.

type: {X : Type u_1} → {Y : Type u_2} → (X → Y) → TopologicalSpace Y → TopologicalSpace X
name: TopologicalSpace.induced
docString:
Given `f : X → Y` and a topology on `Y`,
the induced topology on `X` is the collection of sets
that are preimages of some open set in `Y`.
This is the coarsest topology that makes `f` continuous.

If `f` is a continuous function from topological spaces `X` and `Y`, then for any open set `t` in `Y`, the preimage `f⁻¹(t)` is an open set in `X`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] {f : X → Y},
  Continuous f → ∀ {t : Set Y}, IsOpen t → IsOpen (f ⁻¹' t)
name: IsOpen.preimage
docString: If `f` is a continuous function from topological spaces `X` and `Y`, then for any open set `t` in `Y`, the preimage `f⁻¹(t)` is an open set in `X`.

This theorem states that, given two types `X` and `Y` each equipped with a topological structure (represented by `TopologicalSpace X` and `TopologicalSpace Y` respectively), for any function `f` from `X` to `Y` that is continuous, if a set `t` in `Y` is closed (denoted by `IsClosed t`), then the preimage of `t` under `f` is also closed in `X` (where `f ⁻¹' t` denotes the preimage of `t` under `f`). In other words, continuous functions map closed sets to closed sets under the operation of taking preimages.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] {f : X → Y},
  Continuous f → ∀ {t : Set Y}, IsClosed t → IsClosed (f ⁻¹' t)
name: IsClosed.preimage
docString: This theorem states that, given two types `X` and `Y` each equipped with a topological structure (represented by `TopologicalSpace X` and `TopologicalSpace Y` respectively), for any function `f` from `X` to `Y` that is continuous, if a set `t` in `Y` is closed (denoted by `IsClosed t`), then the preimage of `t` under `f` is also closed in `X` (where `f ⁻¹' t` denotes the preimage of `t` under `f`). In other words, continuous functions map closed sets to closed sets under the operation of taking preimages.

Given `f : X → Y` and a topology on `X`,
the coinduced topology on `Y` is defined such that
`s : Set Y` is open if the preimage of `s` is open.
This is the finest topology that makes `f` continuous.

type: {X : Type u_1} → {Y : Type u_2} → (X → Y) → TopologicalSpace X → TopologicalSpace Y
name: TopologicalSpace.coinduced
docString:
Given `f : X → Y` and a topology on `X`,
the coinduced topology on `Y` is defined such that
`s : Set Y` is open if the preimage of `s` is open.
This is the finest topology that makes `f` continuous.

For any continuous function $f$ between topological spaces $X$ and $Y$, and any open set $U$ in $Y$, the preimage $f^{-1}(U)$ is an open set in $X$.

type:
∀ {X Y : TopCat} (f : X ⟶ Y) (U : Set ↑Y) (p : IsOpen U),
  (TopologicalSpace.Opens.map f).obj { carrier := U, is_open' := p } = { carrier := ⇑f ⁻¹' U, is_open' := ⋯ }
name: TopologicalSpace.Opens.map_obj
docString: For any continuous function $f$ between topological spaces $X$ and $Y$, and any open set $U$ in $Y$, the preimage $f^{-1}(U)$ is an open set in $X$.

This theorem states that, for any types `X` and `Y` and any function `f` from `X` to `Y`, given that `X` and `Y` are topological spaces, if `f` is an open map and continuous, then for any set `s` of type `Y`, the preimage of the closure of `s` under `f` is equal to the closure of the preimage of `s` under `f`. In mathematical terms, if $f : X \rightarrow Y$ is an open and continuous function between two topological spaces, then for any subset $s$ of $Y$, we have $f^{-1}(cl(s)) = cl(f^{-1}(s))$, where $cl(s)$ denotes the closure of the set $s$.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} {f : X → Y} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y],
  IsOpenMap f → Continuous f → ∀ (s : Set Y), f ⁻¹' closure s = closure (f ⁻¹' s)
name: IsOpenMap.preimage_closure_eq_closure_preimage
docString: This theorem states that, for any types `X` and `Y` and any function `f` from `X` to `Y`, given that `X` and `Y` are topological spaces, if `f` is an open map and continuous, then for any set `s` of type `Y`, the preimage of the closure of `s` under `f` is equal to the closure of the preimage of `s` under `f`. In mathematical terms, if $f : X \rightarrow Y$ is an open and continuous function between two topological spaces, then for any subset $s$ of $Y$, we have $f^{-1}(cl(s)) = cl(f^{-1}(s))$, where $cl(s)$ denotes the closure of the set $s$.

The functor from open sets in `X` to `TopCat`,
realising each open set as a topological space itself.

type: (X : TopCat) → CategoryTheory.Functor (TopologicalSpace.Opens ↑X) TopCat
name: TopologicalSpace.Opens.toTopCat
docString:
The functor from open sets in `X` to `TopCat`,
realising each open set as a topological space itself.

The topology induced under an inclusion `f : X → Y` from a discrete topological space `Y`
is the discrete topology on `X`.

See also `DiscreteTopology.of_continuous_injective`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {Y : Type u_2} {f : X → Y} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y]
  [inst_2 : DiscreteTopology Y], Topology.IsEmbedding f → DiscreteTopology X
name: Topology.IsEmbedding.discreteTopology
docString:
The topology induced under an inclusion `f : X → Y` from a discrete topological space `Y`
is the discrete topology on `X`.

See also `DiscreteTopology.of_continuous_injective`.

Let `X` and `Y` be R₁ topological spaces
with Borel σ-algebras and measures `μ` and `ν`, respectively.
Suppose that `μ` is inner regular for finite measure sets with respect to compact sets
and `ν` is a locally finite measure.
Let `f : α → C(X, Y)` be a family of continuous maps
that converges to a continuous map `g : C(X, Y)` in the compact-open topology along a filter `l`.
Suppose that `g` is a measure preserving map
and `f a` is a measure preserving map eventually along `l`.
Then for any finite measure measurable set `s`,
the preimages `f a ⁻¹' s` tend to the preimage `g ⁻¹' s` in measure.
More precisely, the measure of the symmetric difference of these two sets tends to zero.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {X : Type u_2} {Y : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : MeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_2 : BorelSpace X] [inst_3 : R1Space X] [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace Y] [inst_5 : MeasurableSpace Y]
  [inst_6 : BorelSpace Y] [inst_7 : R1Space Y] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {ν : MeasureTheory.Measure Y}
  [inst_8 : μ.InnerRegularCompactLTTop] [inst_9 : MeasureTheory.IsLocallyFiniteMeasure ν] {l : Filter α}
  {f : α → C(X, Y)} {g : C(X, Y)} {s : Set Y},
  Filter.Tendsto f l (nhds g) →
    (∀ᶠ (a : α) in l, MeasureTheory.MeasurePreserving (⇑(f a)) μ ν) →
      MeasureTheory.MeasurePreserving (⇑g) μ ν →
        MeasureTheory.NullMeasurableSet s ν →
          ν s ≠ ⊤ → Filter.Tendsto (fun a => μ (symmDiff (⇑(f a) ⁻¹' s) (⇑g ⁻¹' s))) l (nhds 0)
name: MeasureTheory.tendsto_measure_symmDiff_preimage_nhds_zero
docString:
Let `X` and `Y` be R₁ topological spaces
with Borel σ-algebras and measures `μ` and `ν`, respectively.
Suppose that `μ` is inner regular for finite measure sets with respect to compact sets
and `ν` is a locally finite measure.
Let `f : α → C(X, Y)` be a family of continuous maps
that converges to a continuous map `g : C(X, Y)` in the compact-open topology along a filter `l`.
Suppose that `g` is a measure preserving map
and `f a` is a measure preserving map eventually along `l`.
Then for any finite measure measurable set `s`,
the preimages `f a ⁻¹' s` tend to the preimage `g ⁻¹' s` in measure.
More precisely, the measure of the symmetric difference of these two sets tends to zero.

Let `s, t ⊆ X` be two subsets of a topological space `X`.  If `t ⊆ s` and the topology induced
by `X`on `s` is discrete, then also the topology induces on `t` is discrete.

type: ∀ {X : Type u_5} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] {s t : Set X}, DiscreteTopology ↑s → t ⊆ s → DiscreteTopology ↑t
name: DiscreteTopology.of_subset
docString:
Let `s, t ⊆ X` be two subsets of a topological space `X`.  If `t ⊆ s` and the topology induced
by `X`on `s` is discrete, then also the topology induces on `t` is discrete.

A function from a topological space `X` to a type `Y` is a separated map if any two distinct
points in `X` with the same image in `Y` can be separated by open neighborhoods.

type: {X : Type u_1} → {Y : Sort u_2} → [inst : TopologicalSpace X] → (X → Y) → Prop
name: IsSeparatedMap
docString:
A function from a topological space `X` to a type `Y` is a separated map if any two distinct
points in `X` with the same image in `Y` can be separated by open neighborhoods.

The compact-open topology on the space of continuous maps `C(X, Y)`.

type: {X : Type u_2} → {Y : Type u_3} → [inst : TopologicalSpace X] → [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] → TopologicalSpace C(X, Y)
name: ContinuousMap.compactOpen
docString: The compact-open topology on the space of continuous maps `C(X, Y)`.

The following instance defines the topology on the path space to be induced from the
compact-open topology on the space `C(I,X)` of continuous maps from `I` to `X`.

type: {X : Type u_1} → [inst : TopologicalSpace X] → {x y : X} → TopologicalSpace (Path x y)
name: Path.topologicalSpace
docString:
The following instance defines the topology on the path space to be induced from the
compact-open topology on the space `C(I,X)` of continuous maps from `I` to `X`.

The homeomorphism between `X ⨯ Y` and the set-theoretic product of `X` and `Y`,
equipped with the product topology.

type: (X Y : TopCat) → X ⨯ Y ≅ TopCat.of (↑X × ↑Y)
name: TopCat.prodIsoProd
docString:
The homeomorphism between `X ⨯ Y` and the set-theoretic product of `X` and `Y`,
equipped with the product topology.

The compact-open topology on `C(X, Y)`
is equal to the infimum of the compact-open topologies on `C(s, Y)` for `s` a compact subset of `X`.
The key point of the proof is that for every compact set `K`,
the universal set `Set.univ : Set K` is a compact set as well.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_2} {Y : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y],
  ContinuousMap.compactOpen =
    ⨅ K, ⨅ (_ : IsCompact K), TopologicalSpace.induced (ContinuousMap.restrict K) ContinuousMap.compactOpen
name: ContinuousMap.compactOpen_eq_iInf_induced
docString:
The compact-open topology on `C(X, Y)`
is equal to the infimum of the compact-open topologies on `C(s, Y)` for `s` a compact subset of `X`.
The key point of the proof is that for every compact set `K`,
the universal set `Set.univ : Set K` is a compact set as well.

The presheaf of continuous functions on `X` with values in fixed target topological space
`T`.

type: (X : TopCat) → TopCat → TopCat.Presheaf (Type v) X
name: TopCat.presheafToTop
docString:
The presheaf of continuous functions on `X` with values in fixed target topological space
`T`.

A function to a discrete topological space is continuous if and only if the preimage of every
singleton is open.

type:
∀ {β : Type u_2} {α : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace β] [inst_2 : DiscreteTopology β]
  {f : α → β}, Continuous f ↔ ∀ (b : β), IsOpen (f ⁻¹' {b})
name: continuous_discrete_rng
docString:
A function to a discrete topological space is continuous if and only if the preimage of every
singleton is open.

Given a continuous map `f : X → Y` between topological spaces.
Suppose we have an open cover `V i` of the range of `f`, and an open cover `U i` of `X` that is
coarser than the pullback of `V` under `f`.
To check that `f` is an embedding it suffices to check that `U i → Y` is an embedding for all `i`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_6} {Y : Type u_7} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] (f : X → Y),
  Continuous f →
    ∀ {ι : Type u_4} (U : ι → TopologicalSpace.Opens Y),
      Set.range f ⊆ ↑(iSup U) →
        ∀ (V : ι → Type u_5) [inst_2 : (i : ι) → TopologicalSpace (V i)] (iV : (i : ι) → V i → X),
          (∀ (i : ι), Continuous (iV i)) →
            (∀ (i : ι), f ⁻¹' ↑(U i) ⊆ Set.range (iV i)) →
              (∀ (i : ι), Topology.IsEmbedding (f ∘ iV i)) → Topology.IsEmbedding f
name: isEmbedding_of_iSup_eq_top_of_preimage_subset_range
docString:
Given a continuous map `f : X → Y` between topological spaces.
Suppose we have an open cover `V i` of the range of `f`, and an open cover `U i` of `X` that is
coarser than the pullback of `V` under `f`.
To check that `f` is an embedding it suffices to check that `U i → Y` is an embedding for all `i`.

Let `X` be a normal paracompact topological space (e.g., any extended metric space). Let `E` be
a topological real vector space. Let `t : X → Set E` be a family of convex sets. Suppose that for
each point `x : X`, there exists a vector `c : E` that belongs to `t y` for all `y` in a
neighborhood of `x`. Then there exists a continuous map `g : C(X, E)` such that `g x ∈ t x` for all
`x`. See also `exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_2} {E : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ℝ E]
  [inst_3 : NormalSpace X] [inst_4 : ParacompactSpace X] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace E] [inst_6 : ContinuousAdd E]
  [inst_7 : ContinuousSMul ℝ E] {t : X → Set E},
  (∀ (x : X), Convex ℝ (t x)) → (∀ (x : X), ∃ c, ∀ᶠ (y : X) in nhds x, c ∈ t y) → ∃ g, ∀ (x : X), g x ∈ t x
name: exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local_const
docString:
Let `X` be a normal paracompact topological space (e.g., any extended metric space). Let `E` be
a topological real vector space. Let `t : X → Set E` be a family of convex sets. Suppose that for
each point `x : X`, there exists a vector `c : E` that belongs to `t y` for all `y` in a
neighborhood of `x`. Then there exists a continuous map `g : C(X, E)` such that `g x ∈ t x` for all
`x`. See also `exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local`.

In a topological space with second countable topology, if `f` is a function that sends each
point `x` to a neighborhood of `x`, then for some countable set `s`, the neighborhoods `f x`,
`x ∈ s`, cover the whole space.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} [t : TopologicalSpace α] [inst : SecondCountableTopology α] {f : α → Set α},
  (∀ (x : α), f x ∈ nhds x) → ∃ s, s.Countable ∧ ⋃ x ∈ s, f x = Set.univ
name: TopologicalSpace.countable_cover_nhds
docString:
In a topological space with second countable topology, if `f` is a function that sends each
point `x` to a neighborhood of `x`, then for some countable set `s`, the neighborhoods `f x`,
`x ∈ s`, cover the whole space.

In a topological space with sigma compact topology, if `f` is a function that sends each point
`x` of a closed set `s` to a neighborhood of `x` within `s`, then for some countable set `t ⊆ s`,
the neighborhoods `f x`, `x ∈ t`, cover the whole set `s`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : SigmaCompactSpace X] {f : X → Set X} {s : Set X},
  IsClosed s → (∀ x ∈ s, f x ∈ nhdsWithin x s) → ∃ t ⊆ s, t.Countable ∧ s ⊆ ⋃ x ∈ t, f x
name: countable_cover_nhdsWithin_of_sigmaCompact
docString:
In a topological space with sigma compact topology, if `f` is a function that sends each point
`x` of a closed set `s` to a neighborhood of `x` within `s`, then for some countable set `t ⊆ s`,
the neighborhoods `f x`, `x ∈ t`, cover the whole set `s`.

A map `f : X → Y` is said to be an *open map*,
if the image of any open `U : Set X` is open in `Y`.

type: {X : Type u} → {Y : Type v} → [inst : TopologicalSpace X] → [inst : TopologicalSpace Y] → (X → Y) → Prop
name: IsOpenMap
docString:
A map `f : X → Y` is said to be an *open map*,
if the image of any open `U : Set X` is open in `Y`.

Let `X` be a normal paracompact topological space (e.g., any extended metric space). Let `E` be
a topological real vector space. Let `t : X → Set E` be a family of convex sets. Suppose that for
each point `x : X`, there exists a neighborhood `U ∈ �� X` and a function `g : X → E` that is
continuous on `U` and sends each `y ∈ U` to a point of `t y`. Then there exists a continuous map
`g : C(X, E)` such that `g x ∈ t x` for all `x`. See also
`exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local_const`.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_2} {E : Type u_3} [inst : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : Module ℝ E]
  [inst_3 : NormalSpace X] [inst_4 : ParacompactSpace X] [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace E] [inst_6 : ContinuousAdd E]
  [inst_7 : ContinuousSMul ℝ E] {t : X → Set E},
  (∀ (x : X), Convex ℝ (t x)) →
    (∀ (x : X), ∃ U ∈ nhds x, ∃ g, ContinuousOn g U ∧ ∀ y ∈ U, g y ∈ t y) → ∃ g, ∀ (x : X), g x ∈ t x
name: exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local
docString:
Let `X` be a normal paracompact topological space (e.g., any extended metric space). Let `E` be
a topological real vector space. Let `t : X → Set E` be a family of convex sets. Suppose that for
each point `x : X`, there exists a neighborhood `U ∈ �� X` and a function `g : X → E` that is
continuous on `U` and sends each `y ∈ U` to a point of `t y`. Then there exists a continuous map
`g : C(X, E)` such that `g x ∈ t x` for all `x`. See also
`exists_continuous_forall_mem_convex_of_local_const`.

A family `F : ι → X → α` of functions from a topological space to a uniform space is
*equicontinuous at `x₀ : X`* if, for all entourages `U ∈ �� α`, there is a neighborhood `V` of `x₀`
such that, for all `x ∈ V` and for all `i : ι`, `F i x` is `U`-close to `F i x₀`.

type:
{ι : Type u_1} →
  {X : Type u_3} → {α : Type u_6} → [tX : TopologicalSpace X] → [uα : UniformSpace α] → (ι → X → α) → X → Prop
name: EquicontinuousAt
docString:
A family `F : ι → X → α` of functions from a topological space to a uniform space is
*equicontinuous at `x₀ : X`* if, for all entourages `U ∈ �� α`, there is a neighborhood `V` of `x₀`
such that, for all `x ∈ V` and for all `i : ι`, `F i x` is `U`-close to `F i x₀`.
